snippet: The number of times the city’s police stopped and frisked people has dropped more than 34 percent as sergeants have grown wary of pushing for the stops and officers have expressed anxiety about them.
abstract: Number of times police officers stopped, questioned and frisked people on the streets of New York City dropped by more than 34 percent in the second quarter of 2012; decline reflects a general feeling of unease among officers regarding the tactic, which has come under considerable judicial and media scrutiny; police commanders have also grown wary of pushing for such stops at daily roll calls.

byline.original: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN and WENDY RUDERMAN

lead_paragraph: The number of times the city’s police stopped and frisked people has dropped more than 34 percent as sergeants have grown wary of pushing for the stops and officers have expressed anxiety about them.

headline.seo: Number of New York Police Street Stops Falls 34 Percent
headline.main: Street Stops in New York Fall as Unease Over Tactic Grows
headline.print_headline: Police Stops In New York Drop by 34%
